recipes.title: Adetutu Makes Jollof Rice!
recipes.intro: Let's cook the most famous dish in Nigeria with Adetutu and her family!
recipes.introFact: Nigerian jollof rice is famous for its smoky 'party jollof' flavour!
recipes.completionMessage: Ta-da! Your smoky party jollof is ready to share!
recipes.completionFact: Party jollof cooked over firewood is the most popular style in Nigeria.

steps.story: First, let's rinse the rice until the water is clear!
steps.fact: Splash splash! Rinsing rice makes it fluffy and light.

steps.story: Now chop the tomatoes, onions, and scotch bonnet peppers!
steps.fact: Scotch bonnet peppers give Nigerian jollof its special kick!

steps.story: Pour some oil into the big party pot.
steps.fact: Glug glug! Oil is the base for a great tomato stew.

steps.story: Add the blended tomato mix — this gives jollof its red colour!
steps.fact: Nigerians blend tomatoes, peppers, and onions together for a smooth base.

steps.story: Sprinkle in thyme, curry, and seasoning cubes!
steps.fact: Every Nigerian family has their own secret spice combination!

steps.story: Stir the tomato stew in big circles until it thickens!
steps.fact: Frying the tomatoes until the oil floats on top is the key to great jollof.

steps.story: Now pour in the washed rice!
steps.fact: Long-grain rice works best for Nigerian jollof.

steps.story: Cover the pot tightly and let it cook over the fire... shhh!
steps.fact: The smoky bottom crust is called 'party rice bottom' — many people love it the most!

recipes.title: Adetutu Makes Suya!
recipes.intro: The sun is setting and it's suya time! Let's grill with Adetutu.
recipes.introFact: Suya sellers come out in the evening with their smoky grills!
recipes.completionMessage: Sizzling suya is ready! Wrap it up in newspaper!
recipes.completionFact: Suya is traditionally wrapped in old newspaper and served with sliced onions.

steps.story: Tap to slice the meat into thin strips!
steps.fact: Suya meat is sliced thin so it cooks quickly on the grill.

steps.story: Drag the yaji spice mix onto the meat!
steps.fact: Yaji is made from groundnuts, ginger, and chilli — it's what makes suya special!

steps.story: Thread the meat onto wooden skewers.
steps.fact: Suya sticks are grilled over hot charcoal for a smoky flavour.

steps.story: Hold to grill the suya over the fire!
steps.fact: The best suya is crispy on the outside and juicy inside!

recipes.title: Egusi Soup
recipes.intro: Adetutu and her grandmother are making rich egusi soup together.
recipes.introFact: Egusi soup is made from ground melon seeds — so creamy!
recipes.completionMessage: Egusi soup is thick and delicious! Time to eat!
recipes.completionFact: Egusi soup is one of the most popular soups in Nigeria.

steps.story: Tap to grind the melon seeds into a smooth paste!
steps.fact: Melon seeds are dried and ground to make egusi paste.

steps.story: Drag the palm oil and peppers into the pot.
steps.fact: Palm oil gives the soup its beautiful orange colour.

steps.story: Stir the egusi paste into the pot in big circles!
steps.fact: Stirring helps the egusi form soft, fluffy lumps in the soup.

steps.story: Hold to let the soup simmer with spinach and fish.
steps.fact: Green leafy vegetables are added at the end to keep them fresh and bright.

recipes.title: Pounded Yam
recipes.intro: Adetutu is helping her dad pound yam for dinner — it takes strong arms!
recipes.introFact: Yam is so important in Nigeria there is a New Yam Festival!
recipes.completionMessage: Smooth, stretchy pounded yam is ready for soup!
recipes.completionFact: Pounded yam is eaten by pulling off small pieces and dipping them in soup.

steps.story: Tap to peel and chop the yam into chunks!
steps.fact: Nigerian yams can grow as big as a child's arm!

steps.story: Drag the yam pieces into the boiling water.
steps.fact: Boiling makes the yam soft enough to pound.

steps.story: Now pound the yam! Tap hard and fast!
steps.fact: Traditionally, a big wooden mortar and pestle are used for pounding.

steps.story: Stir and fold until it's smooth and stretchy!
steps.fact: The best pounded yam is smooth with no lumps at all!

recipes.title: Chin Chin
recipes.intro: It's celebration time! Adetutu is making crunchy chin chin with her mum.
recipes.introFact: Chin chin is a crunchy fried snack loved by kids all over Nigeria!
recipes.completionMessage: Crunchy golden chin chin is ready! Crunch crunch!
recipes.completionFact: Chin chin is especially popular during Christmas and celebrations in Nigeria.

steps.story: Tap to mix flour, sugar, and butter into a dough!
steps.fact: Some families add nutmeg or vanilla for extra flavour.

steps.story: Stir the dough until it's smooth and firm!
steps.fact: The dough should be firm enough to roll and cut into shapes.

steps.story: Tap to cut the dough into tiny squares and strips!
steps.fact: Chin chin comes in many shapes — squares, strips, and even twists!

steps.story: Hold to fry the chin chin until golden and crunchy!
steps.fact: Chin chin should be golden brown — not too light, not too dark!
